update.description:
Here is a little christmas pull request.

All command line tools have been refactored into one unified tool: `gz`. This matches functionality of other tools, like `hg` and `git`.

The usage is now: `gz <command> [options]`, where <commands> are string like "topic", "log", "joint", etc.

A complete list of commands is available by using `gz` with no arguments.

Help on each command is available using `gz help <command>`

Tab completion is also in effect. You'll need to manually install this file using: `sudo cp tools/gazebo.bash-completion /etc/bash_completion.d/`. This file will be installed when installing from [debian](#!/osrf/gazebo-release/pull-request/12/support-to-install-bash-completion-script/diff).
update.title: New command line tool
update.reason: Too little time to address all the issues.

content.raw:
There's still some changes in [branch gzmodify_scpeters_shasum](#!/osrf/gazebo/branches/compare/gzmodify_scpeters_shasum..gzmodify#diff) that uses shasum comparisons instead of the header file with super-size string constants (to prevent a reversion of #803).

If you're interested.
content.html:
There's still some changes in branch gzmodify_scpeters_shasum that uses shasum comparisons instead of the header file with super-size string constants (to prevent a reversion of #803).

If you're interested.

content.raw: That spurred me to trying a new approach, and the change in 21cfb9f also fixes the warning (make Command::Help non-virtual since none of the subclasses derive their own form of the method).
content.html: That spurred me to trying a new approach, and the change in 21cfb9f also fixes the warning (make Command::Help non-virtual since none of the subclasses derive their own form of the method).

content.raw: What happens if we use `public: virtual void Help(void);`?
content.html: What happens if we use public: virtual void Help(void);?

content.raw:
`Command::Help()` has no arguments, while `HelpCommand::Help(std::string)` has a string argument. For some reason, clang complains about this unless I put the `using` line in there. I think this lets the compiler use either function depending on the number of arguments.
~~~
In file included from /Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/tools/gz.cc:24:
In file included from /Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/tools/gz_topic.hh:23:
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/tools/gz.hh:231:19: warning: 'gazebo::HelpCommand::Help' hides overloaded virtual function [-Woverloaded-virtual]
    private: void Help(const std::string &_command);
                  ^
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/tools/gz.hh:45:26: note: hidden overloaded virtual function 'gazebo::Command::Help' declared here
    public: virtual void Help();
                         ^
1 warning generated.
~~~
content.html:
Command::Help() has no arguments, while HelpCommand::Help(std::string) has a string argument. For some reason, clang complains about this unless I put the using line in there. I think this lets the compiler use either function depending on the number of arguments.

In file included from /Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/tools/gz.cc:24:
In file included from /Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/tools/gz_topic.hh:23:
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/tools/gz.hh:231:19: warning: 'gazebo::HelpCommand::Help' hides overloaded virtual function [-Woverloaded-virtual]
    private: void Help(const std::string &_command);
                  ^
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/tools/gz.hh:45:26: note: hidden overloaded virtual function 'gazebo::Command::Help' declared here
    public: virtual void Help();
                         ^
1 warning generated.

content.raw:
Thanks. 

The "using Command::Help" is strange. What was the clang warning?
content.html:
Thanks.

The "using Command::Help" is strange. What was the clang warning?

content.raw:
For your consideration:

I have some small changes in [branch gzmodify_scpeters](#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/gzmodify_scpeters..gzmodify#diff) (removing a duplicate Help function and fixing a clang compiler warning).

I also have some bigger changes in [branch gzmodify_scpeters_shasum](#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/gzmodify_scpeters_shasum..gzmodify_scpeters) that replaces the large string comparisons in gz_TEST with shasum comparisons (prevents reversion of #803). Incidentally, working on those changes led to the discover of #1003 as well.
content.html:
For your consideration:

I have some small changes in branch gzmodify_scpeters (removing a duplicate Help function and fixing a clang compiler warning).

I also have some bigger changes in branch gzmodify_scpeters_shasum that replaces the large string comparisons in gz_TEST with shasum comparisons (prevents reversion of #803). Incidentally, working on those changes led to the discover of #1003 as well.

content.raw: Multiple parameters to a single command line option is non-standard. We'd have to wrap the parameter in quotes, parse the string, and check for correctness.
content.html: Multiple parameters to a single command line option is non-standard. We'd have to wrap the parameter in quotes, parse the string, and check for correctness.

content.raw:
* help is now more verbose

* You can tab complete the camera name, or use `gz camera -l`

* Different topic names are created for each instance of gzclient
content.html:
• help is now more verbose

  • You can tab complete the camera name, or use gz camera -l

  • Different topic names are created for each instance of gzclient

content.raw: Yes, gz_roff.py is the command to use. The markdown approach, while convenient, couldn't generate manpages that are needed for `man gz`.
content.html: Yes, gz_roff.py is the command to use. The markdown approach, while convenient, couldn't generate manpages that are needed for man gz.

content.raw:
~~Can this function (`gazebo::Command::HelpCommand::Help`) be removed? Its implementation is identical to `gazebo::Command::Help`, though it is not virtual, so I get a compiler warning with clang.~~
~~~
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/tools/gz.hh:235:19: warning: 'gazebo::HelpCommand::Help' hides overloaded virtual function [-Woverloaded-virtual]
    private: void Help(const std::string &_command);
                  ^
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/tools/gz.hh:45:26: note: hidden overloaded virtual function 'gazebo::Command::Help' declared here
    public: virtual void Help();
                         ^
~~~
EDIT: Actually this is an essential function, but there was also an unused function implementation that I removed in the gzmodify_scpeters branch (058d09c). I also added doxygen for this function and fixed the clang warning in 1c91eba.
content.html:
Can this function (gazebo::Command::HelpCommand::Help) be removed? Its implementation is identical to gazebo::Command::Help, though it is not virtual, so I get a compiler warning with clang.

/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/tools/gz.hh:235:19: warning: 'gazebo::HelpCommand::Help' hides overloaded virtual function [-Woverloaded-virtual]
    private: void Help(const std::string &_command);
                  ^
/Users/scpeters/ws/gazebo_sdformat/src/gazebo/tools/gz.hh:45:26: note: hidden overloaded virtual function 'gazebo::Command::Help' declared here
    public: virtual void Help();
                         ^

EDIT: Actually this is an essential function, but there was also an unused function implementation that I removed in the gzmodify_scpeters branch (058d09c). I also added doxygen for this function and fixed the clang warning in 1c91eba.

content.raw:
It looks like the man page generation is changing too. Is the proposed workflow to run the gz_roff.py command whenever the syntax of gz changes?

Is this an improvement over the existing workflow (shown below)?

* Store man page contents in Markdown
* Auto-generate man page from Markdown
* Use integration test to verify man pages match help text of commands

I kinda like having the man pages in markdown. The roff file is much harder to read.
content.html:
It looks like the man page generation is changing too. Is the proposed workflow to run the gz_roff.py command whenever the syntax of gz changes?

Is this an improvement over the existing workflow (shown below)?

  • Store man page contents in Markdown
  • Auto-generate man page from Markdown
  • Use integration test to verify man pages match help text of commands

I kinda like having the man pages in markdown. The roff file is much harder to read.

content.raw: I started working on this, and then I discovered that the describe and doc commands ignore the sdf version number (#1003).
content.html: I started working on this, and then I discovered that the describe and doc commands ignore the sdf version number (#1003).

content.raw:
* Sounds good; I hadn't thought about `gz stats`. But certainly it would be good to get the help printout if there weren't enough command-line arguments for the given command.

* I was thinking that it would be useful to add an option that will display the names of cameras in the scene. I can make a feature request for that or try to implement it.

* Thanks.
content.html:
• Sounds good; I hadn't thought about gz stats. But certainly it would be good to get the help printout if there weren't enough command-line arguments for the given command.

  • I was thinking that it would be useful to add an option that will display the names of cameras in the scene. I can make a feature request for that or try to implement it.

  • Thanks.

content.raw:
Your first bullet is tricky. Some command line tools will operate with no options (gz stats). Command line tools that follow the `gz` pattern use the `gz help <command>` methodology. How about, on an error output "Please use gz help <command> for more help".

For the second bullet point, I'll add some more documentation in the help.

Third bullet point is a bug in UserCamera. I'll take a look at it.
content.html:
Your first bullet is tricky. Some command line tools will operate with no options (gz stats). Command line tools that follow the gz pattern use the gz help <command> methodology. How about, on an error output "Please use gz help <command> for more help".

For the second bullet point, I'll add some more documentation in the help.

Third bullet point is a bug in UserCamera. I'll take a look at it.

content.raw:
This is really cool; I like command-line tools. I've been playing with `gz` a little bit, and here's a few thoughts that I have (I can make issues for them if we don't want to address them immediately):

* Running `gz` shows a help dialog, but running `gz topic` or `gz physics` without any extra arguments gives no output. This should give the help output for the sub-command.

* The `gz camera` command requires a camera name, but it's not very obvious how to figure out a camera name (my guess is to grep for camera in `gztopic list` or `gz topic -l`). When complaining that no camera names were given, it should provide a list of names to choose from.

* If you have multiple gzclient windows open, I only saw one topic for `gzclient_camera`, so each gzclient camera instance can't be commanded individually. Not a big deal to be honest, but I'm just taking notes here.
content.html:
This is really cool; I like command-line tools. I've been playing with gz a little bit, and here's a few thoughts that I have (I can make issues for them if we don't want to address them immediately):

  • Running gz shows a help dialog, but running gz topic or gz physics without any extra arguments gives no output. This should give the help output for the sub-command.

  • The gz camera command requires a camera name, but it's not very obvious how to figure out a camera name (my guess is to grep for camera in gztopic list or gz topic -l). When complaining that no camera names were given, it should provide a list of names to choose from.

  • If you have multiple gzclient windows open, I only saw one topic for gzclient_camera, so each gzclient camera instance can't be commanded individually. Not a big deal to be honest, but I'm just taking notes here.

content.raw:
Including `test/data/sdf_descriptions_expected.h` is a regression of #803 as well. Would it be acceptable to use shasum's instead of huge string literals (similar to what we did with the pr2 state logs)?

EDIT: I can implement this change if you want.
content.html:
Including test/data/sdf_descriptions_expected.h is a regression of #803 as well. Would it be acceptable to use shasum's instead of huge string literals (similar to what we did with the pr2 state logs)?

EDIT: I can implement this change if you want.

update.description:
Here is a little christmas pull request.

All command line tools have been refactored into one unified tool: `gz`. This matches functionality of other tools, like `hg` and `git`.

The usage is now: `gz <command> [options]`, where <commands> are string like "topic", "log", "joint", etc.

A complete list of commands is available by using `gz` with no arguments.

Help on each command is available using `gz help <command>`

Tab completion is also in effect. You'll need to manually install this file using: `sudo cp tools/gazebo.bash-completion /etc/bash_completion.d/`. This file will be installed when installing from [debian](#!/osrf/gazebo-release/pull-request/12/support-to-install-bash-completion-script/diff).
update.title: New command line tool

content.raw: The current executables are not removed, and their man pages and help text are marked as deprecated.
content.html: The current executables are not removed, and their man pages and help text are marked as deprecated.

content.raw: Including `test/data/pr2_state_log_expected.h` is a regression of #803 (complaints about supersize string literals). I don't think any of the pr2 state strings are referenced from this test, so I think it can be safely removed.
content.html: Including test/data/pr2_state_log_expected.h is a regression of #803 (complaints about supersize string literals). I don't think any of the pr2 state strings are referenced from this test, so I think it can be safely removed.

content.raw:
Are the current executables going to be completely removed? In that case, I would recommend some kind of migration plan. 

* If the same behaviour can be obtained with the gz command, then write a wrapper (same name than the binary) with a deprecation message and run the same using the gz tool would be great. 
* If the behaviour is not replicable, we could have a period (between releases) where the two options exists (gz tool and the previos gzlog, gzsdf, ...) including a deprecation message.
content.html:
Are the current executables going to be completely removed? In that case, I would recommend some kind of migration plan.

  • If the same behaviour can be obtained with the gz command, then write a wrapper (same name than the binary) with a deprecation message and run the same using the gz tool would be great.
  • If the behaviour is not replicable, we could have a period (between releases) where the two options exists (gz tool and the previos gzlog, gzsdf, ...) including a deprecation message.

content.raw: If this is targeted to default, then this warning message should be irrelevant. What should be happening here?
content.html: If this is targeted to default, then this warning message should be irrelevant. What should be happening here?
